qas.question: How many fonts support the majority of Unicode's character repertoire?
What are the fonts that support Unicode referred to as?
Unicode-based fonts are normally focused on supporting what?

answers.text: basic ASCII and particular scripts or sets of characters or symbols

qas.question: What are most of the fonts on the market called?

plausible_answers.text: basic ASCII and particular scripts or sets of characters or symbols

qas.question: Pan unicode fonts only support what?
What normally need more than one or two writing systems?
What is another name for computing environments?

context: Thousands of fonts exist on the market, but <a0_0>fewer than a dozen fonts<a0_0/>—sometimes described as <a1_0>"<b3_0>pan-Unicode<b3_0/>" fonts<a1_0/>—attempt to support the majority of Unicode's character repertoire. Instead, Unicode-based fonts typically focus on supporting only <a2_0><b4_0>basic ASCII and particular scripts or sets of characters or symbols<b4_0/><a2_0/>. Several reasons justify this approach: <b5_0>applications and documents<b5_0/> rarely need to render characters from more than one or two writing systems; fonts tend to demand resources in computing environments; and operating systems and applications show increasing intelligence in regard to obtaining glyph information from separate font files as needed, i.e., <b6_0>font substitution<b6_0/>. Furthermore, designing a consistent set of rendering instructions for tens of thousands of glyphs constitutes a monumental task; such a venture passes the point of diminishing returns for most typefaces.
